title: Planning View
description:
## Summary
Primary view for Town View (70% of user time). Displays epic/task/subtask hierarchy with expandable description previews, dependency indicators, and inline editing via slide-out panel. Enables overseers to review work hierarchy, verify Keepers guidance, and edit beads.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] PlanningView renders hierarchical tree of epics → tasks → subtasks
- [ ] TreeNode shows expandable description preview (click to toggle)
- [ ] TreeNode shows blocked-by indicator with clickable link to blocker
- [ ] TreeNode shows progress summary for parent nodes (e.g., "3/7 tasks")
- [ ] FilterBar integrated at top (status/type/assignee/priority filters)
- [ ] Clicking any node opens IssueEditorPanel slide-out
- [ ] IssueEditorPanel has tabs: Edit | Dependencies | Comments | History
- [ ] Save flow: validate → ConfirmationModal → API call → Toast notification
- [ ] VirtualList used if >100 items for performance
- [ ] Real-time updates via WebSocket refresh tree

## Context
Part of: Town View User Journey Implementation
Keeper Decision: ADR-001 (keeper/decisions/001-user-journey-views.yaml)
Depends on: to-cdih (View Infrastructure epic)

This is Phase 2 - the primary user journey focus.

## Constraints (from Keeper ADR-001)
- MUST use existing TreeNode (extend with new props, don't replace)
- MUST use existing FilterBar (don't recreate filter logic)
- MUST use existing SlideOutPanel for IssueEditorPanel
- MUST use existing IssueEditorForm for edit tab
- MUST use existing DependenciesTab, CommentsTab, HistoryTab
- MUST use existing ConfirmationModal for save confirmation
- MUST use existing VirtualList if >100 items
- TreeNode extension must be backward compatible
- Do NOT create new UI primitives
- Use existing design tokens from src/styles/tokens.css

title: Issue Editor - Phase 4
description:
## Summary
Implement a slide-out panel for viewing and editing issues. All mutations require explicit confirmation with a diff preview. This enables the "Can I fix that?" capability from the project vision.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Slide-out panel opens when clicking an issue
- [ ] Full issue display with all fields
- [ ] Editable fields: status, priority, title, description, labels, assignee
- [ ] Read-only fields displayed: id, created_at, created_by
- [ ] Form validation prevents invalid data
- [ ] Confirmation modal shows diff of changes
- [ ] Save executes bd update command
- [ ] Cancel discards changes and closes panel
- [ ] Dependencies tab shows blockers with add/remove
- [ ] Comments tab shows/adds comments
- [ ] History tab shows audit trail

## Context
Part of Town View roadmap - Phase 4
Integrates with bd CLI for write operations.
Follows "Confirmed Writes" principle - no accidental changes.

## Constraints
- Must use bd CLI for all mutations (no direct file writes)
- Diff must be human-readable
- Panel should not block main dashboard view

title: Slide-out panel component
description: Create SlideOutPanel component that slides from right. 400px width, full height. Backdrop overlay with click-to-close. Smooth animation. Close button in header.

title: Issue display with read-only fields
description: Display full issue in panel: id, type, status, priority, title, description, labels, assignee, created_at, created_by. Read-only fields styled differently from editable.

title: Editable form fields with validation
description: Make fields editable: status dropdown, priority dropdown, title input, description textarea, labels multi-select, assignee dropdown. Validate required fields. Show validation errors inline.

title: Confirmation modal with diff preview
description: Show confirmation modal before save. Display diff of changes: field name, old value, new value. Green for additions, red for removals. Confirm/Cancel buttons.

title: bd CLI integration for save
description: Execute bd update command on confirm. Build command from changed fields. Handle success/error responses. Show toast notification on result. Close panel on success.

title: Dependencies tab
description: Add Dependencies tab to editor panel. List blockers and blocked-by. Add dependency button opens selector. Remove dependency with confirmation. Uses bd dep commands.

title: Comments tab
description: Add Comments tab showing issue comments. Display comment author, timestamp, body. Add comment form at bottom. Uses bd comments commands for CRUD.

title: History tab
description: Add History tab showing audit trail. List all changes: timestamp, actor, field, old→new value. Scrollable list, newest first. Read-only view.

title: Roadmap View - Phase 3
description:
## Summary
Build an epic hierarchy tree visualization showing the roadmap structure. Users can navigate work items as a tree, expand/collapse nodes, and filter by various criteria. This provides the "What's coming?" view from the project vision.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Tree component renders epic → issue → task hierarchy
- [ ] Nodes expand/collapse on click
- [ ] Keyboard navigation works (arrow keys, enter to expand)
- [ ] Status icons displayed: ○ open, ◐ in_progress, ● blocked, ✓ closed
- [ ] Priority color coding applied to nodes
- [ ] Filter controls for status work
- [ ] Filter controls for type work
- [ ] Filter controls for assignee work
- [ ] Filter controls for priority range work
- [ ] Click node opens issue in editor panel
- [ ] Dependency arrows toggle (optional feature)

## Context
Part of Town View roadmap - Phase 3
Builds on Phase 2 dashboard infrastructure.
Tree visualization is central to understanding work breakdown.

## Constraints
- Must handle deeply nested hierarchies gracefully
- Performance must remain smooth with 100+ nodes
- Collapse state should persist during session

title: Tree hierarchy data structure
description: Create data model for epic→issue→task hierarchy. Build tree from flat bead list using parent relationships. Export functions: buildTree(), getChildren(), getAncestors().

title: Tree node component with expand/collapse
description: Create TreeNode component with expand/collapse toggle. Indentation by depth level. Chevron icon rotates on expand. Smooth height animation for children reveal.

title: Status and priority icons for tree nodes
description: Add status icons to tree nodes: ○ open, ◐ in_progress, ● blocked, ✓ closed. Apply priority color coding to node text/border. Icons should be consistent with design system.

title: Keyboard navigation for tree
description: Implement keyboard nav: ↑↓ to move focus, ←→ to collapse/expand, Enter to select/open. Focus indicator visible. Tab order respects tree structure.

title: Filter controls for tree view
description: Add filter bar: status dropdown, type dropdown, assignee dropdown, priority range slider. Filters hide non-matching nodes but keep ancestors visible. Clear all button.

title: Dependency arrows visualization
description: Optional toggle to show dependency arrows between nodes. Draw SVG arrows for blocks/blocked-by relationships. Arrows should curve gracefully and not overlap excessively.

title: WebSocket reconnection loop causes page freeze
description:
dispatched_by: mayor

CRITICAL: useWebSocket.ts has a reconnection loop that causes thousands of 'Insufficient resources' errors. Page freezes after seconds of use.

## Symptoms
- Console floods with 'Insufficient resources' errors
- Page becomes unresponsive
- Browser tab may crash

## Root Cause
Missing exponential backoff on WebSocket reconnection attempts.

## Fix Required
1. Add exponential backoff to reconnection logic
2. Cap maximum reconnection attempts
3. Add connection state tracking to prevent duplicate connections

## Files
- frontend/src/hooks/useWebSocket.ts
close_reason: Fixed: WebSocket hook now has exponential backoff, max attempts, and connection state tracking

title: View Infrastructure
description:
## Summary
Foundation infrastructure for Town View's three-view architecture (Planning, Monitoring, Audit). This epic establishes the view switching mechanism and container components that enable the primary user journey.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] ViewSwitcher component renders three tabs: Planning | Monitoring | Audit
- [ ] Clicking a tab updates the active view in uiStore
- [ ] App.tsx renders the correct view based on viewMode state
- [ ] View containers (PlanningView, MonitoringView, AuditView) exist as placeholders
- [ ] Default view is Planning when app loads
- [ ] View state persists during rig switching
- [ ] Storybook stories exist for ViewSwitcher

## Context
Part of: Town View User Journey Implementation
Keeper Decision: ADR-001 (keeper/decisions/001-user-journey-views.yaml)

This is Phase 1 - must complete before Phases 2-4 can begin.
Phases 2, 3, 4 (Planning, Monitoring, Audit views) depend on this infrastructure.

## Constraints (from Keeper ADR-001)
- ViewSwitcher MUST use existing Button styles or match design tokens
- ViewSwitcher MUST store state in uiStore (extend existing store)
- Do NOT create new Zustand stores - extend uiStore with viewMode field
- Follow existing file naming conventions (kebab-case)
- Include Storybook stories for ViewSwitcher

- Backend rig list endpoint

title: Monitoring View
description:
## Summary
Secondary view for Town View (20% of user time). Displays agent status cards, in-flight work, and stuck detection. Enables overseers to see which agents are working, what they're working on, and identify problems.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] MonitoringView renders grid of AgentCards
- [ ] AgentCards show: name, role, state (idle/working/stuck), hooked bead
- [ ] Stuck detection: highlight agents working >15min on same bead
- [ ] In-flight work section shows all in_progress issues with assigned agent
- [ ] Recently completed section shows last 24h closed issues
- [ ] Clicking agent card opens their hooked bead in IssueEditorPanel
- [ ] Real-time updates via WebSocket

## Context
Part of: Town View User Journey Implementation
Keeper Decision: ADR-001 (keeper/decisions/001-user-journey-views.yaml)
Depends on: to-cdih (View Infrastructure epic)

This is Phase 3 - secondary user journey focus.

## Constraints (from Keeper ADR-001)
- MUST use existing AgentCard component
- MUST extract from RigDashboard, do NOT duplicate logic
- Do NOT create new AgentCard variants
- Stuck detection logic goes in MonitoringView, not AgentCard
- Use existing IssueEditorPanel for bead viewing (from Phase 2)

title: Digest: mol-witness-patrol
description: Patrol 6: Nuked nux and furiosa (POLECAT_DONE). 5 polecats remaining.

title: Audit View
description:
## Summary
Tertiary view for Town View (10% of user time). Displays completed work comparison (planned vs actual), convoy selection, and metrics. Enables overseers to audit what was accomplished vs what was assigned.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] AuditView renders ConvoySelector at top
- [ ] DateRangePicker filters completed work by date
- [ ] List of completed work shows AssignmentComparison for each item
- [ ] MetricsDisplay shows summary stats (completed count, scope changes, etc.)
- [ ] Clicking item expands full AssignmentComparison detail
- [ ] Filter by convoy shows only work from that convoy

## Context
Part of: Town View User Journey Implementation
Keeper Decision: ADR-001 (keeper/decisions/001-user-journey-views.yaml)
Depends on: to-cdih (View Infrastructure epic)

This is Phase 4 - tertiary user journey focus.
May require backend endpoint for convoy-filtered completed work.

## Constraints (from Keeper ADR-001)
- MUST use existing ConvoySelector
- MUST use existing AssignmentComparison
- MUST use existing DateRangePicker
- MUST use existing MetricsDisplay
- Do NOT create new comparison or metrics components
- If backend changes needed, coordinate with backend team

Fix: Replace issues.map() at lines 237-246 with VirtualList component.

Requirements:

- Set itemHeight to match IssueRow height (~48px)
- Use getKey to extract issue.id
- Maintain dependency arrows functionality
- Keep flash animation for updated issues
close_reason: Integrated VirtualList into RigDashboard - replaced issues.map() with VirtualList component for performance with 3000+ issues. Keeper ADR-001.

title: Dashboard View - Phase 2
description:
## Summary
Enhance the rig dashboard with agent cards, improved filtering, and real-time updates. This phase transforms the basic issue list into a full monitoring dashboard showing agent status, work progress, and live updates.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Agent cards component renders for each agent type (witness, refinery, crew, polecats)
- [ ] Agent state displayed (idle/working/stuck) with visual indicators
- [ ] Hooked bead shown on each agent card
- [ ] Issue list shows status badges with color coding
- [ ] Issue list shows priority badges (P0 red → P4 gray)
- [ ] Filter controls work for status dropdown
- [ ] Filter controls work for issue_type dropdown
- [ ] Live updates reflected in UI without page refresh
- [ ] Visual feedback (flash/highlight) when data updates via WebSocket

## Context
Part of Town View roadmap - Phase 2
Builds on Phase 1 (Tracer Bullet) which established basic data flow.
Design tokens and components from DESIGN_SYSTEM.md apply.

## Constraints
- Must use existing WebSocket infrastructure
- Follow design system color tokens for status/priority
- Agent data comes from bd list with agent type filter

title: Agent cards component with status indicators
description: Create AgentCard component displaying agent type (witness, refinery, crew, polecat), state (idle/working/stuck) with visual indicators, and currently hooked bead. Uses design system tokens for status colors.

title: Issue list status badges
description: Add status badges to issue list items. Use design system color tokens: open=blue, in_progress=yellow, blocked=red, closed=green. Badge should be pill-shaped with status icon.

title: Issue list priority badges
description: Add priority badges to issue list. Color coding: P0=red, P1=orange, P2=yellow, P3=blue, P4=gray. Badge displays Pn label with appropriate background.

title: Filter controls for status and type
description: Add dropdown filter controls above issue list. Status dropdown: all/open/in_progress/blocked/closed. Type dropdown: all/bug/feature/task/epic/chore. Filters update list in real-time.

title: WebSocket real-time update integration
description: Connect dashboard to WebSocket for live updates. Subscribe to bead change events. Update local state when beads change. Handle connection/reconnection gracefully.

title: Visual feedback for data updates
description: Add flash/highlight animation when data updates via WebSocket. Brief background color pulse on changed rows. Subtle but noticeable feedback that something updated.

title: Update App.tsx view routing
description: parent: to-cdih

title: Implement the solution
description:
Do the actual implementation work.

**Working principles:**
- Follow existing codebase conventions
- Make atomic, focused commits
- Keep changes scoped to the assigned issue
- Don't gold-plate or scope-creep

**Commit frequently:**
```bash
# After each logical unit of work:
git add <files>
git commit -m "<type>: <description> (to-oaz.5)"
```

Commit types: feat, fix, refactor, test, docs, chore

**Discovered work:**
If you find bugs or improvements outside your scope:
```bash
bd create --title "Found: <description>" --type bug --priority 2
# Note the ID, continue with your work
```

Do NOT fix unrelated issues in this branch.

**If stuck:**
Don't spin for more than 15 minutes. Mail Witness:
```bash
gt mail send <rig>/witness -s "HELP: Stuck on implementation" -m "Issue: to-oaz.5
Trying to: <what you're attempting>
Problem: <what's blocking you>
Tried: <what you've attempted>"
```

**Exit criteria:** Implementation complete, all changes committed.
close_reason: Orphaned polecat work molecules - no active session

title: Run tests and verify coverage
description:
Verify your changes don't break anything and are properly tested.

**1. Run the full test suite:**
```bash
go test ./...               # For Go projects
# Or appropriate command for your stack
```

**ALL TESTS MUST PASS.** Do not proceed with failures.

**2. If tests fail:**
- Read the failure output carefully
- Determine if your change caused it:
  - If yes: Fix it. Return to implement step if needed.
  - If no (pre-existing): File a bead, but still must pass for your PR

```bash
# Check if failure exists on main:
git stash
git checkout main
go test ./...
git checkout -
git stash pop
```

**3. Verify test coverage for new code:**
- New features should have tests
- Bug fixes should have regression tests
- If you added significant code without tests, add them now

**4. Run any other quality checks:**
```bash
# Linting (if configured)
golangci-lint run ./...

# Build check
go build ./...
```

**Exit criteria:** All tests pass, new code has appropriate test coverage.
close_reason: Orphaned polecat work molecules - no active session

title: Self-review changes
description:
Review your own changes before running tests.

**1. Review the diff:**
```bash
git diff origin/main...HEAD     # All changes vs main
git log --oneline origin/main..HEAD  # All commits
```

**2. Check for common issues:**

| Category | Look For |
|----------|----------|
| Bugs | Off-by-one, null handling, edge cases |
| Security | Injection, auth bypass, exposed secrets |
| Style | Naming, formatting, code organization |
| Completeness | Missing error handling, incomplete paths |
| Cruft | Debug prints, commented code, TODOs |

**3. Fix issues found:**
Don't just note them - fix them now. Amend or add commits as needed.

**4. Verify no unintended changes:**
```bash
git diff --stat origin/main...HEAD
# Only files relevant to to-oaz.5 should appear
```

If you accidentally modified unrelated files, remove those changes.

**Exit criteria:** Changes are clean, reviewed, and ready for testing.
close_reason: Orphaned polecat work molecules - no active session

title: Clean up workspace
description:
Ensure workspace is pristine before handoff.

**1. Check for uncommitted changes:**
```bash
git status
```
Must show "working tree clean". If not:
- Commit legitimate changes
- Discard garbage: `git checkout -- .`

**2. Check for untracked files:**
```bash
git status --porcelain
```
Should be empty. If not:
- Add to .gitignore if appropriate
- Remove if temporary: `rm <file>`
- Commit if needed

**3. Check stash:**
```bash
git stash list
```
Should be empty. If not:
- Pop and commit: `git stash pop && git add -A && git commit`
- Or drop if garbage: `git stash drop`

**4. Push your branch:**
```bash
git push -u origin $(git branch --show-current)
```

**5. Verify nothing left behind:**
```bash
git status                  # Clean
git stash list              # Empty
git log origin/main..HEAD   # Your commits
git diff origin/main...HEAD # Your changes (expected)
```

**Exit criteria:** Branch pushed, workspace clean, no cruft.
close_reason: Orphaned polecat work molecules - no active session

title: Prepare work for review
description:
Verify work is complete and ready for merge queue.

**Note:** Do NOT close the issue. The Refinery will close it after successful merge.
This enables conflict-resolution retries without reopening closed issues.

**1. Verify the issue shows your work:**
```bash
bd show to-oaz.5
# Status should still be 'in_progress' (you're working on it)
```

**2. Add completion notes:**
```bash
bd update to-oaz.5 --notes "Implemented: <brief summary of what was done>"
```

**3. Sync beads:**
```bash
bd sync
```

**Exit criteria:** Issue updated with completion notes, beads synced.
close_reason: Orphaned polecat work molecules - no active session

title: Set up working branch
description:
Ensure you're on a clean feature branch ready for work.

**1. Check current branch state:**
```bash
git status
git branch --show-current
```

**2. If not on a feature branch, create one:**
```bash
# Standard naming: polecat/<your-name> or feature/<issue-id>
git checkout -b polecat/<name>
```

**3. Ensure clean working state:**
```bash
git status                  # Should show "working tree clean"
git stash list              # Should be empty
```

If dirty state from previous work:
```bash
# If changes are relevant to this issue:
git add -A && git commit -m "WIP: <description>"

# If changes are unrelated cruft:
git stash push -m "unrelated changes before to-oaz.5"
# Or discard if truly garbage:
git checkout -- .
```

**4. Sync with main:**
```bash
git fetch origin
git rebase origin/main      # Get latest, rebase your branch
```

If rebase conflicts:
- Resolve them carefully
- Test after resolution
- If stuck, mail Witness

**Exit criteria:** You're on a clean feature branch, rebased on latest main.
close_reason: Orphaned polecat work molecules - no active session

title: mol-polecat-work
description:
Full polecat work lifecycle from assignment through completion.

This molecule guides a polecat through a complete work assignment. Each step
has clear entry/exit criteria and specific commands to run. A polecat can
crash after any step and resume from the last completed step.

## Polecat Contract (Self-Cleaning Model)

You are a self-cleaning worker. You:
1. Receive work via your hook (pinned molecule + issue)
2. Work through molecule steps using `bd ready` / `bd close <step>`
3. Complete and self-clean via `gt done` (submit + nuke yourself)
4. You are GONE - Refinery merges from MQ

**Self-cleaning:** When you run `gt done`, you push your work, submit to MQ,
nuke your sandbox, and exit. There is no idle state. Done means gone.

**Important:** This formula defines the template. Your molecule already has step
beads created from it. Use `bd ready` to find them - do NOT read this file directly.

**You do NOT:**
- Push directly to main (Refinery merges from MQ)
- Close your own issue (Refinery closes after merge)
- Wait for merge (you're gone after `gt done`)
- Handle rebase conflicts (Refinery spawns fresh polecats for that)

## Variables

| Variable | Source | Description |
|----------|--------|-------------|
| issue | hook_bead | The issue ID you're assigned to work on |

## Failure Modes

| Situation | Action |
|-----------|--------|
| Tests fail | Fix them. Do not proceed with failures. |
| Blocked on external | Mail Witness for help, mark yourself stuck |
| Context filling | Use gt handoff to cycle to fresh session |
| Unsure what to do | Mail Witness, don't guess |
close_reason: Orphaned polecat work molecules - no active session

title: Load context and verify assignment
description:
Initialize your session and understand your assignment.

**1. Prime your environment:**
```bash
gt prime                    # Load role context
bd prime                    # Load beads context
```

**2. Check your hook:**
```bash
gt hook               # Shows your pinned molecule and hook_bead
```

The hook_bead is your assigned issue. Read it carefully:
```bash
bd show to-oaz.5           # Full issue details
```

**3. Check inbox for additional context:**
```bash
gt mail inbox
# Read any HANDOFF or assignment messages
```

**4. Understand the requirements:**
- What exactly needs to be done?
- What files are likely involved?
- Are there dependencies or blockers?
- What does "done" look like?

**5. Verify you can proceed:**
- No unresolved blockers on the issue
- You understand what to do
- Required resources are available

If blocked or unclear, mail Witness immediately:
```bash
gt mail send <rig>/witness -s "HELP: Unclear requirements" -m "Issue: to-oaz.5
Question: <what you need clarified>"
```

**Exit criteria:** You understand the work and can begin implementation.
close_reason: Orphaned polecat work molecules - no active session

title: Verify tests pass on main
description:
Check if the codebase is healthy BEFORE starting your work.

**The Scotty Principle:** Don't walk past a broken warp core. But also don't
let someone else's mess consume your entire mission.

**1. Check tests on main:**
```bash
git stash                   # Save your branch state
git checkout origin/main
go test ./...               # Or appropriate test command
```

**2. If tests PASS:**
```bash
git checkout -              # Back to your branch
git stash pop               # Restore state
```
Continue to implement step.

**3. If tests FAIL on main:**

Make a judgment call:

| Situation | Action |
|-----------|--------|
| Quick fix (<15 min) | Fix it, commit to main, then continue |
| Medium fix (15-60 min) | Fix if it blocks your work, else file bead |
| Big fix (>1 hour) | File bead, notify Witness, proceed with your work |

**Quick fix path:**
```bash
# Fix the issue
git add <files>
git commit -m "fix: <description> (pre-existing failure)"
git push origin main
git checkout -
git stash pop
git rebase origin/main      # Get your fix
```

**File and proceed path:**
```bash
bd create --title "Pre-existing test failure: <description>" --type bug --priority 1

gt mail send <rig>/witness -s "NOTICE: Main has failing tests" -m "Found pre-existing test failures on main.
Filed: <bead-id>
Proceeding with my assigned work (to-oaz.5)."

git checkout -
git stash pop
```

**Context consideration:**
If fixing pre-existing failures consumed significant context:
```bash
gt handoff -s "Fixed pre-existing failures, ready for assigned work" -m "Issue: to-oaz.5
Fixed: <what you fixed>
Ready to start: implement step"
```
Fresh session continues from implement.

**Exit criteria:** Tests pass on main (or issue filed), ready to implement.
close_reason: Orphaned polecat work molecules - no active session

title: Submit work and self-clean
description:
Submit your work and clean up. You cease to exist after this step.

**Self-Cleaning Model:**
Once you run `gt done`, you're gone. The command:
1. Pushes your branch to origin
2. Creates an MR bead in the merge queue
3. Nukes your sandbox (worktree removal)
4. Exits your session immediately

**Run gt done:**
```bash
gt done
```

You should see output like:
```
✓ Work submitted to merge queue
  MR ID: gt-xxxxx
  Source: polecat/<name>
  Target: main
  Issue: to-oaz.5
✓ Sandbox nuked
✓ Session exiting
```

**What happens next (not your concern):**
- Refinery processes your MR from the queue
- Refinery rebases and merges to main
- Refinery closes the issue
- If conflicts: Refinery spawns a FRESH polecat to re-implement

You are NOT involved in any of that. You're gone. Done means gone.

**Exit criteria:** Work submitted, sandbox nuked, session exited.
close_reason: Orphaned polecat work molecules - no active session

title: Polish - Phase 6
description:
## Summary
Final polish phase adding keyboard navigation, dark mode, performance optimization, and error resilience. This phase ensures the application is production-ready and pleasant to use.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Full keyboard navigation throughout app
- [ ] Keyboard shortcuts documented and discoverable
- [ ] Dark mode toggle works
- [ ] Dark mode colors follow design system
- [ ] Performance profiled and optimized
- [ ] Virtual scrolling for large lists
- [ ] Graceful error handling (no white screens)
- [ ] Offline resilience - shows cached data when backend unavailable
- [ ] Loading states for all async operations
- [ ] Error boundaries catch component failures

## Context
Part of Town View roadmap - Phase 6 (Final)
Builds on all previous phases.
Focus is UX refinement, not new features.

## Constraints
- No new features - only polish existing
- Must maintain bundle size reasonable
- Accessibility standards should be met
close_reason: All Phase 6 tasks completed - Town View roadmap complete!

title: Keyboard navigation system
description: Global keyboard shortcuts: / for search, g+d dashboard, g+r roadmap, g+a audit, Esc close panels. Focus management. Shortcut hints in UI. Help modal with all shortcuts.

title: Dark mode toggle and theming
description: Add dark mode toggle in header. Implement CSS custom properties for theme colors. Persist preference in localStorage. System preference detection as default.

title: Performance optimization with virtual scrolling
description: Implement virtual scrolling for long lists (100+ items). Only render visible items. Smooth scroll behavior. Maintain scroll position on data updates.

title: Error handling and boundaries
description: Add React error boundaries around major sections. Graceful fallback UI on component crash. Log errors for debugging. Recovery actions where possible.

title: Offline resilience
description: Cache last known data in localStorage/IndexedDB. Show cached data when backend unavailable. Clear indicator of offline state. Auto-reconnect and refresh when online.

title: Loading states for async operations
description: Add loading spinners/skeletons for all async operations. Skeleton screens for initial load. Inline spinners for updates. Disable buttons during submit.

title: Audit View - Phase 5
description:
## Summary
Build the audit view for reviewing polecat work vs assignments. This answers "What happened?" by showing convoy history, agent timelines, and work comparison.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Convoy selector dropdown lists available convoys
- [ ] Date range picker for filtering audit period
- [ ] Assignment vs completion side-by-side comparison
- [ ] Original bead state shown (what was dispatched)
- [ ] Final bead state shown (what was delivered + close reason)
- [ ] Agent timeline shows who touched what, when
- [ ] Diff view shows description changes over time
- [ ] Metrics displayed: time to complete, re-assignments, conflicts
- [ ] Export audit report (optional)

## Context
Part of Town View roadmap - Phase 5
Critical for oversight of autonomous agent work.
Convoy data comes from convoy-type beads.

## Constraints
- Must handle convoys with many issues
- Timeline should be zoomable/scrollable
- Historical data may be large - consider pagination

title: Convoy selector component
description: Dropdown to select convoy for audit. List convoys by date/name. Show convoy status (active/completed). On select, load convoy data for audit view.

title: Date range picker
description: Add date range picker for filtering audit period. Start date and end date inputs. Preset buttons: today, this week, this month. Filter events within range.

title: Assignment vs completion comparison
description: Side-by-side view: left shows original assignment (bead when dispatched), right shows final state (bead when closed). Highlight differences in status, description, labels.

title: Agent timeline component
description: Horizontal timeline showing agent activity. Each agent as a swim lane. Events plotted by timestamp. Hover shows event details. Zoom/scroll for navigation.

title: Diff view for bead changes
description: Show description changes over time as unified diff. Split view: before/after. Syntax highlighting for markdown. Navigate between change versions.

title: Metrics display
description: Dashboard cards showing: time to complete (avg, min, max), re-assignments count, merge conflicts count. Calculated from audit events. Visual indicators for anomalies.

title: Extend TreeNode with expandable description preview
description: parent: to-8qpk

title: mol-witness-patrol
description:
Per-rig worker monitor patrol loop.

The Witness is the Pit Boss for your rig. You watch polecats, nudge them toward
completion, verify clean git state before kills, and escalate stuck workers.

**You do NOT do implementation work.** Your job is oversight, not coding.

## Ephemeral Polecat Model

Polecats are truly ephemeral - done at MR submission, recyclable immediately:

```
Polecat lifecycle: spawning → working → mr_submitted → nuked
MR lifecycle:      created → queued → processed → merged (Refinery handles)
```

Once a polecat's branch is pushed (cleanup_status=clean), the polecat can be
nuked immediately. The MR continues independently in the Refinery. If conflicts
arise, Refinery creates a NEW conflict-resolution task for a NEW polecat.

**Key principle**: Polecat lifecycle is separate from MR lifecycle.

## Design Philosophy

This patrol follows Gas Town principles:
- **Discovery over tracking**: Observe reality each cycle, don't maintain state
- **Events over state**: POLECAT_DONE mail triggers immediate cleanup
- **Ephemeral by default**: Clean polecats are nuked immediately, no waiting
- **Cleanup wisps for exceptions**: Only created when intervention needed
- **Task tool for parallelism**: Subagents inspect polecats, not molecule arms

## Patrol Shape (Linear, Deacon-style)

```
inbox-check ─► process-cleanups ─► check-refinery ─► survey-workers
                                                            │
         ┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
         ▼
  check-timer-gates ─► check-swarm ─► ping-deacon ─► patrol-cleanup ─► context-check ─► loop-or-exit
```

No dynamic arms. No fanout gates. No persistent nudge counters.
State is discovered each cycle from reality (tmux, beads, mail).

The Witness is the Pit Boss for your rig. You watch polecats, nudge them toward
completion, verify clean git state before kills, and escalate stuck workers.

**You do NOT do implementation work.** Your job is oversight, not coding.

## Ephemeral Polecat Model

Polecats are truly ephemeral - done at MR submission, recyclable immediately:

```
Polecat lifecycle: spawning → working → mr_submitted → nuked
MR lifecycle:      created → queued → processed → merged (Refinery handles)
```

Once a polecat's branch is pushed (cleanup_status=clean), the polecat can be
nuked immediately. The MR continues independently in the Refinery. If conflicts
arise, Refinery creates a NEW conflict-resolution task for a NEW polecat.

**Key principle**: Polecat lifecycle is separate from MR lifecycle.

## Design Philosophy

This patrol follows Gas Town principles:
- **Discovery over tracking**: Observe reality each cycle, don't maintain state
- **Events over state**: POLECAT_DONE mail triggers immediate cleanup
- **Ephemeral by default**: Clean polecats are nuked immediately, no waiting
- **Cleanup wisps for exceptions**: Only created when intervention needed
- **Task tool for parallelism**: Subagents inspect polecats, not molecule arms

## Patrol Shape (Linear, Deacon-style)

```
inbox-check ─► process-cleanups ─► check-refinery ─► survey-workers
                                                            │
         ┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
         ▼
  check-timer-gates ─► check-swarm ─► ping-deacon ─► patrol-cleanup ─► context-check ─► loop-or-exit
```

No dynamic arms. No fanout gates. No persistent nudge counters.
State is discovered each cycle from reality (tmux, beads, mail).
